did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Estes family papers contain Civil War correspondence from Aaron Estes, soldier in the 10th Texas Infantry. Other materials in the collection include legal and financial papers.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Aaron Douglas Estes (1820-1864) was born on 1820 May 10 to Hiram M. Estes (1797-1854) and Lucy Anna Richardson Estes (1799-1845) in Franklin County, Tennessee. He married Elizabeth Lucretia Wilson Estes, originally from Alabama, in Morgan County, Missouri, in 1838. They came to Texas in 1840, and settled in McLennan county, though they later moved close to Hillsboro in Hill County. They had nine children together.

When the Civil War came, Aaron Estes enlisted into Company B, 10th Texas Infantry, under Colonel Allison Nelson. The regiment was captured at Arkansas Post on 1863 January 11. Estes would have been imprisoned with the rest of his regiment for a time in Camp Douglas, Chicago, a Union prisoner of war camp, until they were exchanged and sent south.

After being exchanged, the regiment was consolidated with the 6th Texas Infantry and the 15th Texas Cavalry (dismounted) and assigned to Cleburne's division, Army of Tennessee. Estes and his unit participated in battles at Chickamauga and Chattanooga and the Atlanta Campaign. Aaron Estes was killed in the Battle of Jonesborough on 1864 August 31, the final battle of the Atlanta Campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Estes family papers contain correspondence, legal papers, sales receipts, tax receipts, muster rolls, land surveys, and a hair album. The letters include information about the 10th Texas Infantry's defense of Arkansas Post. One letter describes Estes' experience at Camp Douglass prisoner of war camp before he and the rest of his unit were exchanged. The letters then describe the 10th Texas' involvement in the Atlanta campaign as part of Granbury's Texas Brigade, Cleburne's Division. The letters end before the Battle of Jonesborough on August 31, where Aaron Estes was killed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, the collection was housed in folders with titles. No dates were present on the folders. Paper clips, staples, or other fasteners had already been removed.

Currently, the collection is contained in two series: I. Aaron Estes Civil War Letters and II. Collected Family Materials. Materials are arranged chronologically, and most letters have a copy of the letter filed with them.
